title: 115_s1776
content: The Act may be cited as the "Agricultural Energy Programs Reauthorization Act of 2017". The Act includes a section on the Biobased Markets Program. Section 9002 of the Farm Security and Rural Investment Act of 2002 is amended to include renewable chemicals in the biobased products labeling program. The Secretary will provide education and outreach to stakeholders regarding this voluntary labeling program. The Secretary, in consultation with the Administrator, will provide education and outreach to stakeholders regarding the voluntary labeling program for renewable chemicals and biobased products. The Secretary and the Secretary of Commerce will develop NAICS codes for manufacturers of renewable chemicals and biobased products. Additionally, there will be a national testing center registry established. In subsection (h)(2), amendments are made to subparagraphs (B)(ii) and (C), and a new requirement is added for a description of biobased products procured in the previous year. In subsection (i), funding amounts are increased for fiscal years 2019 through 2023. Subsection (j) is revised to include specific details on what it encompasses. In subsection (j), the amendment includes products produced from biologically captured and reused carbon. SEC. 3. Assistance for biorefinery, renewable chemical, and biobased product manufacturing. Section 9003 of the Farm Security and Rural Investment Act of 2002 is amended to include renewable chemical or biobased product technology in biorefineries, with mandatory funding for loan guarantees under this section. The Secretary will allocate $75,000,000 annually for loan guarantees under this section until 2023. SEC. 4. The Farm Security and Rural Investment Act of 2002 is amended to allocate $5,000,000 annually for advanced biofuels from 2018 to 2023. SEC. 5. The Rural Energy for America Program is also updated. The definition of a renewable energy system under the Farm Security and Rural Investment Act of 2002 is expanded to include components necessary for energy distribution and storage. The Farm Security and Rural Investment Act of 2002 now includes funding of $150,000,000 annually for renewable energy systems, with a portion allocated for infrastructure and storage. The Farm Security and Rural Investment Act of 2002 allocates up to 30% of funding for renewable energy and energy efficiency technologies. SEC. 6 amends funding for biomass research and development to $20,000,000 annually from 2019 to 2023. SEC. 7 extends the Feedstock Flexibility Program for bioenergy producers until 2023. SEC. 8 focuses on biofuels, biobased products, and wildland fire protection. Section 9011 of the Farm Security and Rural Investment Act of 2002 is amended to focus on biofuels, biobased product feedstock, and wildland fire protection program. This includes redesignating paragraphs and updating terminology within the program. Section 9011 of the Farm Security and Rural Investment Act of 2002 is amended to include algae, animal waste, and byproducts as biofuel feedstock. Clauses within the program are also revised to reflect these changes. The Secretary may provide payment for transportation costs of projects removing eligible material for hazardous woody fuel reduction in wildland areas at risk from wildfire or in need of restoration. Projects must prioritize protection of human life, structures in the wildland-urban interface, and municipal water supplies. Additionally, $20,000,000 is authorized for discretionary funding for fiscal years 2019 through 2023. The Secretary must allocate not less than $50,000,000 for transportation payments and not less than 10 percent for other purposes. The Secretary will allocate $70,000,000 for transportation payments for hazardous woody fuel reduction projects. Additionally, $20,000,000 is authorized for discretionary funding for fiscal years 2019 through 2023. Not less than 10 percent, and not greater than 50 percent, of the remaining amount will be allocated for other purposes. The Farm Security and Rural Investment Act of 2002 is amended to extend the Community Wood Energy Program until 2023. The effective date for these amendments is October 1, 2018.
